reviews.reviewText:
üåü Ward‚Äôs Lake ‚Äì Shillong‚Äôs Little Slice of Peace

Ward‚Äôs Lake is a beautiful escape right in the heart of Shillong. Surrounded by manicured gardens, colorful flowers, and shaded walking paths, it‚Äôs the kind of place where you instantly slow down. The highlight for me was the charming wooden bridge in the middle‚Äîit gives you a picture-perfect view of the lake and the reflections of the trees.

Entry is just ‚Çπ20, and you can rent a pedal boat for a relaxed ride on the water. It‚Äôs clean, well-maintained, and perfect for families, couples, or even solo travelers looking for a calm stroll. The orchids and seasonal blooms add a splash of color, making it a photographer‚Äôs delight.

In short: peaceful, well-kept, and a refreshing green break from the city‚Äôs buzz.

The lake is named after the Chief Commissioner of Assam, Sir William Ward. It's also known as Pollock's Lake. It's a must visit for anyone who visit Shillong. Situated right in the middle of the city, it has its own charm and beauty. It attracts trendy tourists all round the year.

Ward‚Äôs Lake in Shillong was my second travel destination, and I had a really peaceful and pleasant experience there.

The park is quite large and spread across a big area. It is located right along the main road, so it‚Äôs easy to find. There is an entry ticket, and plastic bottles or any kind of plastic items are not allowed inside, which helps keep the place clean and eco-friendly.

Inside the park, there are many trees, a big lake with a lot of fish, and small birds flying around. Visitors often feed the fish, and the overall atmosphere is very calm and close to nature.

The park is well maintained. Cleaning staff are present and regularly keep the area clean. There is also a small section near a pool where you can rent traditional local dresses and take photos, which is a fun experience. A small caf√© inside the park offers light snacks and drinks, so you can sit and relax for a while.

This place is good for walking, relaxing, spending time in nature, and clicking photos. I would definitely recommend visiting it if you're in Shillong.

Wards Lake is a charming little escape in the heart of Shillong. The serene water, surrounded by beautifully maintained gardens and walking paths, makes it perfect for a peaceful stroll or just sitting quietly and soaking in the calm. The wooden bridge across the lake adds a lovely touch, and if you‚Äôre lucky, you might spot a few colorful fish swimming by. It‚Äôs not a place for adventure seekers, but if you appreciate quiet moments in nature, this spot won‚Äôt disappoint.
Beautiful and nice ambiance. Ticket is only Rs. 20/- . Plastic free lake. Overall it is a beautiful lake.

The place get young and happening during cherry blossoms festival.

Ward‚Äôs Lake is a tranquil oasis nestled right in the heart of Shillong, offering a perfect blend of natural beauty, colonial charm, and modern-day accessibility. Whether you're a local looking for a serene walk or a traveler exploring Meghalaya, this lake is a must-visit.

Historical Significance:
Constructed in 1894, Ward‚Äôs Lake was conceptualized by Sir William Erskine Ward (then Chief Commissioner of Assam) and designed by Fitzwilliam Thomas Pollock. It was built under the supervision of Colonel Hopkins. The lake, also referred to as Pollock‚Äôs Lake or Nan Polok, reflects Shillong‚Äôs colonial-era heritage and continues to be one of the most beloved landmarks of the city.

What to Expect:

A beautifully maintained man-made lake surrounded by botanical gardens, seasonal flower beds, and a picturesque wooden bridge.

Boating facilities are available for those looking to enjoy a peaceful ride across the water.

Ideal for leisurely walks, photography, and quiet relaxation.

The area is rich in flora and frequented by ducks, birds, and fish, making it perfect for nature lovers.

Ticketing Details (As per latest on-site information):

Adults: ‚Çπ20

Children (6 to 12 years): ‚Çπ10

Senior citizens and persons with disabilities (with ID): ‚Çπ10

Foreign tourists (children below 12 years): ‚Çπ20

Morning Joggers: ‚Çπ200/month (Timing: 5:00 AM to 9:00 AM; lake remains closed on Tuesdays for joggers)

Still Camera: ‚Çπ0.50

Video Camera: ‚Çπ100 per unit

Wedding Shoots: ‚Çπ1000 per day

Film Shooting: ‚Çπ3000

DSLR/Digital Camera: ‚Çπ20

UPI Payments Accepted

Plastic-free zone: Visitors are encouraged to keep the area clean and plastic-free.

Tips for Visitors:

Open from morning to evening; early mornings are ideal for walks.

Avoid visiting on Tuesday mornings if you're coming for jogging or photography, as the lake remains closed for maintenance.

Carry cash for quick entry, though UPI is now accepted at the counter.

Keep your ticket safe ‚Äì it must be retained while inside the premises.

Final Verdict:
Ward‚Äôs Lake offers a peaceful and refreshing experience that combines nature, heritage, and local culture. The management does a commendable job maintaining the premises, and the ticketing is affordable for all age groups. It‚Äôs clean, scenic, and well worth the time. Whether you're in Shillong for a day or a week, don‚Äôt miss this charming spot.

Highly recommended.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: All Saints' Cathedral, located near Police Bazaar in Shillong, is a historic Anglican church that showcases stunning Victorian architecture and intricate religious symbolism. Built in 1902 during the British colonial era, this Gothic-style marvel features beautiful stained glass windows depicting biblical scenes. Despite being damaged by an earthquake in 1897, the cathedral was meticulously reconstructed and remains a major tourist attraction with its elegant wooden colonial-style design.

reviews.reviewText: Just dropped by for a visit to have a good look at this Church. It‚Äôs an Anglican Church in Shillong. Constructed beautifully and used some nice colours for the exterior with a nice lawn area outside. The inside of the Church is really simple and quaint. But we loved the view of this Church.

All Saints' Cathedral in Shillong is a remarkable architectural gem that showcases the unique charm of wooden structures, making it a standout in the region. The cathedral's design beautifully combines Gothic elements with local craftsmanship, featuring intricate woodwork and a warm, inviting atmosphere. As you enter, the lofty ceilings and stained glass windows create a serene and uplifting ambiance that enhances your experience.
Built in 1902, All Saints' Cathedral holds significant historical importance as one of the oldest churches in Shillong. It reflects the British colonial influence on the area while also serving as a vital part of the local community. The church has witnessed numerous historical events and has been a central place of worship for generations.
The cathedral is not only a place of worship but also a site of cultural significance, often hosting community events and celebrations. Its peaceful surroundings and beautiful gardens make it a lovely spot for reflection or a leisurely stroll.
In summary, All Saints' Cathedral is a must-visit for anyone in Shillong, offering a captivating blend of stunning architecture and rich history. Whether you‚Äôre an architecture enthusiast, a history buff, or simply seeking a peaceful retreat, this cathedral provides a memorable experience that highlights the city‚Äôs cultural heritage.

placeMetadata.description: 20th-century Catholic church with numerous works of art, stained-glass windows & sculptures.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled in the serene Laitumkhrah locality of Shillong, the Cathedral of Mary Help of Christians stands as a stunning testament to faith and artistry. This 20th-century Roman Catholic church, built by German missionaries in 1913, is renowned for its breathtaking stained-glass windows and intricate sculptures that adorn its Gothic architecture. Following a devastating fire in 1936 that destroyed the original wooden structure, this magnificent cathedral was constructed on an artificial sand basin designed to withstand earthquakes.
placeMetadata.address: HV9R+CFP, Laitumkhrah, Shillong, Meghalaya 793003, India

reviews.reviewText:
A Must-Visit Landmark in Shillong

The Cathedral of Mary Help of Christians in Laitumkhrah is one of the most iconic and peaceful places in Shillong. Steeped in history, the Cathedral stands on the site of the first Catholic Church built in 1913 by German missionaries. Though the original structure was destroyed by fire on Good Friday in 1936, the current cathedral‚Äîbuilt in the 1940s and consecrated in 1947‚Äîcarries a strong legacy of resilience, faith, and beauty.

The architecture is strikingly modern Gothic, built on beds of sand to withstand earthquakes. Inside, the terracotta artwork and stained-glass windows‚Äîcrafted in Germany and France‚Äîbeautifully depict the life of Jesus Christ and various Biblical scenes.

Don‚Äôt miss the Grotto Chapel of Our Lady of Lourdes and the Calvary Hill, where a life-size bronze crucifixion statue and the Stations of the Cross add to the spiritual atmosphere. It‚Äôs especially moving during Good Friday when special devotions are held here.

The Cathedral offers not just a place for prayer, but also a serene escape from the bustle of the city. Whether you're religious or simply appreciate art, history, and quiet reflection, this place is worth visiting.

Tip: Visit in the evening for a peaceful ambiance, and take a few moments to read the information board at the entrance‚Äîit gives rich context to everything you'll see.

Nestled atop the serene Laitumkhrah hill in Shillong, the majestic Cathedral of Mary Help of Christians isn‚Äôt just a place of worship ‚Äì it‚Äôs a sanctuary where time pauses, noise fades, and the soul takes a deep, quiet breath. A striking piece of architecture wrapped in calm and character, this cathedral is as much a spiritual experience as it is a historical one.

A Heavenly Blend of Faith and Form
Built in 1936, the cathedral is dedicated to the Blessed Virgin Mary, and is the principal church of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Shillong. Its design is an elegant mix of Gothic and Indigenous styles, blending high arches, stained glass windows, and local artistry into a structure that feels both majestic and grounded.

What sets it apart, quite literally, is its location on a hillock, making it visible from miles away ‚Äî like a lighthouse of faith. The sky-blue exterior contrasts stunningly with Shillong‚Äôs often misty skies, creating a canvas that photographers, poets, and peaceful wanderers would agree is divine inspiration at work.

Fun Facts to File Under ‚ÄúDid You Know?‚Äù
- The cathedral was constructed on sand-filled grounds to withstand earthquakes ‚Äî a wise move in a seismically active region.
- It houses the grave of Archbishop Hubert D‚ÄôRosario, a revered figure who served the region with tireless devotion.
- During Christmas and Easter, the cathedral is a beacon of celebration, with elaborate nativity displays, lights, and hymns that can warm even the chilliest Shillong night.

Reverent Review
The cathedral isn‚Äôt just a monument, it‚Äôs a meditative experience in blue and white. Whether you're religious or simply a lover of quiet architecture, this place offers solace. The chirping of birds, the whiff of incense, and the echo of prayers create a soundtrack that stays with you long after you leave.

Pro Tip: Visit on a weekday morning. Less crowd, more calm. And don‚Äôt forget to light a candle ‚Äì sometimes, peace starts with a flicker.

The Cathedral of Mary Help of Christians in Shillong is a serene and stunning place of worship. Its striking architecture, peaceful atmosphere, and beautiful stained glass windows make it a true spiritual and visual experience. Surrounded by greenery and perched on a quiet hill, it‚Äôs a perfect spot for reflection and appreciation of local history and faith. A must-see landmark in the city.

A very beautiful church with lots of history and many sayings. It has a double stored building type structure which is pretty good. Most Beautiful Church in Shillong. A Soulful & Unforgettable Experience!

Even though I‚Äôm a Hindu, I‚Äôve always felt drawn to peaceful, spiritual places  and this church in Shillong truly touched my heart. It's beautifully built across a large area and has two levels  both the upper and lower sections are stunning and calm.

The entire church is so picturesque that I couldn‚Äôt stop taking photos. Every corner was beautiful and serene. But beyond the beauty, what made this visit unforgettable was a very special moment.

I wanted to light candles as a prayer, but unfortunately, there was no shop nearby. I was a little disappointed. Just then, a local person saw me and kindly offered me a candle. When I tried to pay, he smiled and said,
"You‚Äôve come to God‚Äôs house  it‚Äôs free. Please take it."
That moment was so pure and touching. I‚Äôll never forget his kindness  it made my entire trip feel truly blessed.

This place is not just a church; it‚Äôs an experience of peace, humility, and connection  beyond religion. Whether you're spiritual or not, this is a place you must visit in Shillong.

Highly recommended  truly a must-visit! üôè‚ú®

Nestled in a remarkably peaceful setting, the only Shia Mosque in Shillong stands as a testament to both serene spirituality and architectural grandeur. Beyond its religious significance, this place offers a holistic experience, embracing education, literature, and community engagement.

The mosque hosts a school committed to providing high-quality education, shaping young minds with a focus on excellence. Adjacent to this educational institution is a sprawling library, housing an extensive collection of books on Islam. What sets this library apart is its inclusivity, featuring materials in a multitude of languages, thereby becoming a beacon of knowledge accessible to a diverse audience.

The architecture extends beyond the prayer halls, with a meticulously designed sitting area that beckons visitors to immerse themselves in the world of literature. The intention behind its layout is evident‚Äîa space that not only accommodates reading but encourages it, fostering an atmosphere of reflection and tranquility.

Particularly noteworthy are the Islamic classes held in the library on specific days. This community-oriented initiative further establishes the mosque as a center for both spiritual and intellectual growth. It opens its doors not only to the Muslim community but also extends a warm welcome to individuals of all backgrounds, making it a cultural and educational hub for Shillong.

In essence, this mosque transcends religious boundaries, emerging as a cultural landmark and educational haven. Its architectural magnificence, coupled with a commitment to knowledge and community, renders it a must-visit destination‚Äîeven for those outside the Muslim faith.

placeMetadata.name: Motphran

sources.snippet: The ‚ÄúStone of France‚Äù which is locally known as "Motphran" was built in memory of the 26th Khasi Labour Corps who served in France under the British during World War 1. This place is also a hub for the market. Carved on the memorial is this quotation from Horace: Dulce et   decorum est pro patria mori. Wilfred Owen scornfully, called this line which means ‚Äúit is sweet and dignified to die for our homeland‚Äù . Address: Iewduh, Bara Bazaar, Shillong. East Khasi Hills District, Shillong
sources.shortName: Monuments in Shillong, Architectural Buildings in Shillong

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Motphran, also known as the Monument of France, is a memorial honoring Khasi porters who lost their lives during World War I. Located near Bara Bazaar, this site has become a popular spot for thrift shopping. The area's thrift stores have moved from the main road to beneath a bridge, creating an even more unique and edgy atmosphere for visitors to explore and enjoy.

placeMetadata.name: Seng Khasi Hall

sources.snippet: The hall was formed by Seng Khasi, which is an assembly of the Khasi community. It was founded in 1899 by a committee of sixteen members in 899. The Khasis‚Äô celebrate the Annual thanksgiving of this festival in this hall with certain customs and rituals, Shad Suk Mynsiem, is celebrated here during spring time with much festivity.
sources.shortName: Monuments in Shillong, Architectural Buildings in Shillong

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Seng Khasi Hall, established in 1899 by a committee of sixteen members, serves as an assembly for the Khasi community. It is the venue for various cultural celebrations and rituals, including the Annual Thanksgiving festival and the vibrant Shad Suk Mynsiem festival during springtime. This hall offers insights into the customs and traditions of the Khasis, making it a valuable resource for learning about their rich heritage.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb: Nestled in the lush hills of Meghalaya, Shillong is a city that beautifully marries nature with a rich tapestry of architectural styles. From the serene All Saints' Cathedral, with its Victorian charm, to the modern lines of the Laitumkhrah Presbyterian Church, each structure tells a story of the city's diverse cultural heritage. As you wander through the streets, you'll encounter the grand Shillong Centenary Monument, a tribute to the city's historical significance, and the majestic Raj Bhawan, which offers stunning views of the picturesque Ward's Lake. But Shillong's architectural wonders don't stop at the well-known landmarks. Hidden gems like the Brookside Adventist Higher Secondary School and the vibrant Seng Khasi Hall showcase the community's spirit and traditions. Whether you're strolling down the charming Tripura Castle Rd or exploring the bustling Khyndailad market, the city's unique blend of colonial history and modern design invites you to discover its many layers. So grab your camera and get ready to explore the architectural beauty that Shillong has to offer!

placeMetadata.name: Elephant Falls, Shillong

sources.snippet: Elephant Falls, the city‚Äôs most impressive waterfall, is a three-tiered cascading beauty and one of the best places to visit in Shillong throughout the year. Because of a large nearby rock that bears an uncanny resemblance to an elephant, the British gave it the moniker ‚Äúelephant rock.‚Äù The rock was demolished in an earthquake, thus it can no longer be seen. The Elephant Falls are actually ‚Äúthree step waterfalls,‚Äù with the first one being a big one tucked away among the lush greenery, the second one being thin water threads, and the third one being the most stunning and clear falls rushing against the background of a dark colour.

sources.snippet: At a distance of 12 km from Shillong Bus Stand, Elephant Falls is a stunning waterfalls located in the outskirts of Shillong, the capital city of Meghalaya. It is one of the prominent waterfalls in Meghalaya and among the prime places to visit in Shillong.The waterfall is located in Upper Shillong area within the Eastern Air Command of Indian Air Force. The Khasi tribe named it Ka Kshaid Lai Pateng Khohsiew, meaning Three Steps Waterfalls.

We visited Elephant Falls yesterday, and the experience was truly memorable. The drive through the hills was beautiful ‚Äî green, breezy, and calming, setting the perfect tone before even reaching the falls.

Google Maps was accurate and guided us right to the location without any confusion, which was a huge help on those hilly roads.

Once there, you‚Äôll need to climb down a set of stairs to witness the three levels of the waterfall ‚Äî each with its own charm. The view is breathtaking and the sound of rushing water surrounded by greenery is incredibly refreshing.

There‚Äôs a small caf√© at the entrance, perfect for grabbing a bite or a hot coffee. We got caught in the rain and were completely drenched ‚Äî that hot cup of coffee afterward felt amazing!

There‚Äôs also a market inside the premises where you can buy souvenirs or local handmade items ‚Äî a great stop if you‚Äôre looking to take a little memory back home.

The entry fee is ‚Çπ100 per person, and the area is fairly well-maintained.

If you‚Äôre in Shillong, Elephant Falls is a must-visit ‚Äî for the views, the peaceful vibe, and the complete nature experience.

reviews.reviewText: The view is great. Must visit place in shillong. The lake is awesome and provides fresh air. There is a bit of walking to reach the lake but it's a great photoshoot place. A Tranquil Jewel Just Outside Shillong

Umiam Lake is, without doubt, one of the crown jewels of Meghalaya. Just a short drive from Shillong‚Äôs hustle - around 15 km from Police Bazar - this place opens up into a vast, glimmering expanse of water cradled by rolling green hills. It‚Äôs the kind of place that makes you pause, breathe, and forget time altogether.

The surroundings are peaceful and beautifully kept - perfect for an afternoon stroll or simply sitting by the shore with a flask of tea. Boating here is a real treat - hop onto a shared speedboat or take a kayak out if you fancy a bit more quiet. Either way, the views are sublime, especially as the sun starts to dip and the sky reflects off the lake‚Äôs calm surface.

Before reaching the lake entrance, there‚Äôs a lovely little viewpoint worth stopping for. You‚Äôll find some fast food stalls there too - nothing fancy, but great for a quick bite with a view.

Whether you‚Äôre into photography, nature, or just a bit of soul-soothing stillness, Umiam Lake is a must. A gentle reminder of how spectacular simplicity can be.

üåü Umiam Lake View ‚Äì A Peaceful Jewel Near Shillong

I visited Umiam Lake Viewpoint on my way to Shillong, and it instantly became one of my favorite spots in Meghalaya. The moment you step out, you‚Äôre greeted with an incredible 180-degree view of calm blue waters surrounded by rolling green hills. I went around late afternoon, and the golden light made the whole place look magical.

The entry fee was just ‚Çπ50, and there are benches to sit and simply soak in the scenery. It‚Äôs a great place for photography‚Äîwhether you‚Äôre after sweeping landscapes or peaceful close-ups of the lake. If you have extra time, you can try boating or just stroll in the nearby garden.

In short: serene, scenic, and worth stopping even if you‚Äôre only passing by. Perfect for a relaxing pause before diving back into Meghalaya‚Äôs adventures.

placeMetadata.name: Don Bosco Museum

sources.snippet: At a distance of 3 km from Shillong Bus Stand, Don Bosco Center for Indigenous Cultures is a well-known museum situated within the Sacred Heart Church premises in Shillong. Also known as Don Bosco Museum, it is one of the most popular museums in Shillong and among the must visit Tourist Places in Shillong.Opened in 2003, Don Bosco Museum is a privately owned museum under the control of Salesian order of the Catholic Church which enlightens the history and culture of the north eastern states of Assam, Arunachal Pradesh, Meghalaya, Manipur, Mizoram, Nagaland and Tripura. It is a three-in-one institution that combines a museum with a research and publication center.

Hailed as Asia's largest Museum of Indigenous Cultures, the Don Bosco Museum is the house of the beautiful culture and tradition of North East India. It has 16 laid out galleries that showcase artefacts, paintings, figures significant to the Northeastern culture.

reviews.reviewText:
This is a must visit in Shillong with a ticket cost of just 20 rupees per head, I highly recommend to explore this place in order to understand the cultures and heritage of all the North Eastern States
We went there with minimal knowledge and we got to experience most of the cultures.
Also would recommend taking an option to click pictures. It‚Äôll help you in making memories
We took many pictures and had really fun at the view point as well.
Spare at-least 2-3 hrs
It‚Äôs air conditioned and well maintained, The staff is friendly too and there‚Äôs a store with lot of options to buy from.

The Don Bosco Museum is definitely worth a visit if you're interested in the culture and traditions of Northeast India.
The exhibits are well-curated, with a lot of colorful displays and detailed information.
The building itself is impressive and the skywalk at the top gives a nice panoramic view of Shillong.
However, some sections felt a bit repetitive, and a few interactive displays were not working when we visited.
The museum spans seven floors with 17 galleries including cafeteria. It takes 1-2 hrs to see all details.
Every floor has clean toilets. Whole premises is neat and clean.
Tickets for Adults Rs.100, Children Rs.50, Camera Rs.100. (they allow only camera pass holder to take photos, no other devices allowed)
It can get crowded during peak hours too. Overall, a good experience, but with a few improvements, it could be even better.

Don Bosco Museum in Meghalaya is a must-visit! The ticket is very affordable at just ‚Çπ20, with an extra charge for photography. The museum beautifully showcases the rich cultural heritage of the Seven Sister states and the one brother ‚Äî Sikkim. Each floor is dedicated to different aspects of tribal life, art, history, and traditions of Northeast India, including Gangtok.

The displays are well-organized, informative, and visually appealing. There's also a small caf√© near the ticket counter where you can get coffee and sandwiches at very reasonable prices ‚Äî a nice touch after exploring the museum.

Highly recommended for anyone interested in learning about the diverse cultures of Northeast India.

It's a well maintained museum and the skywalk gives a vast panoramic view of the Shillong town.
It's a must visit if you're in Shillong. The ticket is cheap with extra charges for mobiles and cameras.
The museum beautifully showcases the rich cultural heritage of the Seven Sister states and one brother Sikkim. Each floor is dedicated to different aspects of tribal life, their belongings and how they manage their livelihood.
One can understand the difference between the cultures of the seven states in a very lucid way.

It beautifully showcases the rich culture and traditions of North-East India across 7 well-organized floors. The exhibits are informative, and the rooftop skywalk offers a great view of the city. Clean, well-maintained, and perfect for anyone curious about tribal heritage.

went there, and at first, it wasn‚Äôt very crowded outside. I had to buy a ticket before entering. After getting the ticket, a staff member took me inside.

Once inside, they provided an ID card, and I had to pay separately to take photos and videos.

They informed me that there are seven floors, and there was also a small guide booklet available. The booklet explained everything‚Äîwhat‚Äôs on each floor and where to find it.

Each even-numbered floor had a restroom, accessible to everyone‚Äîincluding both men and women.

I was exploring the place alone‚Äîthere was no guide, and not many people around either. But I really enjoyed it. The place was very well-maintained and quite impressive.

What I liked the most was the lighting system. They had motion detectors‚Äîso whenever I entered a room, the lights would automatically turn on, and once I left, they would turn off.

At the very top, on the terrace, you could actually see the entire view of the surroundings‚Äîit‚Äôs the highest point. The view from there was absolutely amazing. It was truly the best moment for me.

I visited around sunset, and that golden, peaceful moment felt truly special to me‚Äîit was absolutely beautiful.

After exploring everything, it was almost closing time. There were also a few things available for purchase near the main entrance.

I would definitely recommend this as a must-visit place, especially for the stunning top view and sunset experience. It was truly worth it!

I visited the Don Bosco Museum yesterday, and it‚Äôs hands down the biggest museum I‚Äôve ever explored! With multiple floors filled with exhibits, it offers a deep dive into the rich culture, history, and traditions of Northeast India ‚Äî truly impressive and educational.

The entry ticket is ‚Çπ100 per person, and if you want to take photos, there‚Äôs an additional ‚Çπ100 photo pass (no videos allowed). Be careful ‚Äî if you‚Äôre caught clicking pictures without the pass, there‚Äôs a fine. So better to get it beforehand.

The Skywalk on the top floor is a major highlight! It gives you a breathtaking 360¬∞ view of Shillong city, and it was honestly one of the most memorable parts of the visit.

I also really enjoyed the space and science section, which was interactive and fun. There‚Äôs no guide, but everything is well-labelled and easy to follow at your own pace.

Reaching the place is easy with Google Maps, though the final turn can be a bit confusing due to narrow alleys that show as roads on the map ‚Äî but just follow it patiently and you‚Äôll get there.

There‚Äôs free parking available with enough space for both two-wheelers and four-wheelers, which is a big plus.

If you‚Äôre in Shillong, I highly recommend adding Don Bosco Museum to your itinerary ‚Äî it‚Äôs informative, fun, and gives you a true appreciation of the region‚Äôs diversity.

Seven storeys of fascinating visuals, colours, and treasures ‚Äì that is one way to describe Don Bosco Museum. You will first be greeted by the traditional wear of all the different North-Eastern communities as you enter the building, including well-researched sections on the neighbouring countries like Bhutan, Myanmar, and Nepal. The photography section is loaded with rare photos ‚Äì you can spend hours lost exploring these snippets of tribal life taken across the region and spanning many generations.
Don't forget to go on the terrace for the amazing and wonderful view of the City ‚ù§Ô∏è.

A must-visit destination for aviation and military enthusiasts! Located near Elephant Falls in Upper Shillong, this museum offers a unique glimpse into the glorious history of the Indian Air Force.

The outdoor display is impressive ‚Äî featuring real aircraft like the MiG-21, Mi-4 helicopter, Hunter fighter, and Caribou transport plane. Inside, the galleries are well-maintained, showcasing war medals, uniforms, aircraft models, missiles, and even a working flight simulator. One section also highlights the rich culture of Northeast India, which adds a unique regional touch.

The museum is clean, organized, and has decent facilities like restrooms, parking, and a small souvenir shop. Entry is very affordable (‚Çπ30 for adults), but carry a valid Indian photo ID as it's mandatory for entry. Foreign nationals are not allowed due to security reasons.

Photography is allowed in most outdoor areas, and you can easily spend 1‚Äì2 hours exploring everything. I highly recommend this place to anyone visiting Shillong!

‚úÖ Best Time to Visit: Wednesday to Sunday (closed on Mondays & Tuesdays)
‚úÖ Don't miss the aircraft cockpit you can sit in!

Air Force Museum Shillong

Located 59 km from Umiam Lake or Bara Pani Lake. 13 km from Shillong bus stand. It is situated inside the Air Force Eastern Command Campus.

The museum is open from 9.30 am to 2 pm, 2.30 pm to 5 pm (closed on Wednesdays & Sundays).
Entry Fee: Nil.

Witness models of missiles and aircraft, learn about the Indian Air Force-Eastern Command‚Äôs history, and see the rare pictures of the wars between India, China, and Pakistan.
This museum is a tribute to the glorious past of the defence of our nation. It hosts aircraft models, actual machines and technology demonstrations used by the IAF Eastern Command. The museum displays the uniforms worn by the air force pilots, missiles, rockets, pictures of Indo-China War and Indo-Pakistan War, medals and miniature models of air crafts.
****

It's an amazing experience to visit the museum. Make sure you carry a valid ID as they will register your name and ID details for security reasons. The museum is quite small but has a good collection of miniature aircraft models and lots of photos. The area outside has life size helicopter, planes, etc. that are just massive and awesome.

Tucked away in the quiet hills of Shillong‚Äôs Upper Mawprem area, the Indian Air Force Museum is the kind of place where Top Gun meets East Khasi Hills. It‚Äôs not just for aviation buffs or war-history enthusiasts ‚Äî it‚Äôs a full-throttle, high-altitude experience even for those who don‚Äôt know a MiG from a Maggi!

When History Takes Flight
Maintained by the Eastern Air Command of the Indian Air Force, this museum is an ode to courage, engineering marvels, and that inexplicable human urge to defy gravity. The moment you step in, you‚Äôre greeted by a real fighter jet standing guard outside, which is the closest you can get to touching supersonic history without triggering a security breach.

Inside? It's a buffet of:
- Fighter aircraft models, including Sukhoi and MiG variants (no, not the ones from your toy box).
- Ammunition and uniforms worn during different wars, including the 1965 and 1971 Indo-Pak conflicts.
- An impressive war-time photo gallery that could give National Geographic a run for its money.
- Oh, and an actual ejector seat. Yes, the kind you‚Äôd want to use in Monday morning meetings!

Did You Know?
- The museum showcases pieces of enemy aircraft shot down during wartime ‚Äî talk about souvenirs with attitude and swag.
- There‚Äôs a replica of a remotely piloted vehicle (RPV) that once did spy duty ‚Äî proof that drones had ancestors too.
- This is one of the few Air Force museums in India open to civilians, and probably the only one where you can hear birds chirp outside as jets silently roar from within.

Radar Review
The museum is neat, compact, and surprisingly insightful. Kids will love it, adults will get misty-eyed, and every Indian heart will swell just a bit with pride. The only thing missing is popcorn ‚Äî because this place deserves a background score!

Pro Tip: Entry is free, but carry an ID. And no touching the missiles ‚Äî they don‚Äôt take kindly to unsolicited hugs.

The weekends, particularly Saturday and Sunday, see the park buzzing with families enjoying their leisure time, taking advantage of the pleasant surroundings.

Adding to the park‚Äôs appeal is the vibrant street food scene just outside its gates. Here, visitors can indulge in a variety of delicious snacks, making for a perfect end to a day of play and relaxation. Overall, this park is a beautiful, serene retreat where nature and joy converge, offering a perfect escape from everyday life.

reviews.reviewText:
A Must-Visit Landmark in Shillong

The Cathedral of Mary Help of Christians in Laitumkhrah is one of the most iconic and peaceful places in Shillong. Steeped in history, the Cathedral stands on the site of the first Catholic Church built in 1913 by German missionaries. Though the original structure was destroyed by fire on Good Friday in 1936, the current cathedral‚Äîbuilt in the 1940s and consecrated in 1947‚Äîcarries a strong legacy of resilience, faith, and beauty.

The architecture is strikingly modern Gothic, built on beds of sand to withstand earthquakes. Inside, the terracotta artwork and stained-glass windows‚Äîcrafted in Germany and France‚Äîbeautifully depict the life of Jesus Christ and various Biblical scenes.

Don‚Äôt miss the Grotto Chapel of Our Lady of Lourdes and the Calvary Hill, where a life-size bronze crucifixion statue and the Stations of the Cross add to the spiritual atmosphere. It‚Äôs especially moving during Good Friday when special devotions are held here.

The Cathedral offers not just a place for prayer, but also a serene escape from the bustle of the city. Whether you're religious or simply appreciate art, history, and quiet reflection, this place is worth visiting.

Tip: Visit in the evening for a peaceful ambiance, and take a few moments to read the information board at the entrance‚Äîit gives rich context to everything you'll see.

Nestled atop the serene Laitumkhrah hill in Shillong, the majestic Cathedral of Mary Help of Christians isn‚Äôt just a place of worship ‚Äì it‚Äôs a sanctuary where time pauses, noise fades, and the soul takes a deep, quiet breath. A striking piece of architecture wrapped in calm and character, this cathedral is as much a spiritual experience as it is a historical one.

A Heavenly Blend of Faith and Form
Built in 1936, the cathedral is dedicated to the Blessed Virgin Mary, and is the principal church of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Shillong. Its design is an elegant mix of Gothic and Indigenous styles, blending high arches, stained glass windows, and local artistry into a structure that feels both majestic and grounded.

What sets it apart, quite literally, is its location on a hillock, making it visible from miles away ‚Äî like a lighthouse of faith. The sky-blue exterior contrasts stunningly with Shillong‚Äôs often misty skies, creating a canvas that photographers, poets, and peaceful wanderers would agree is divine inspiration at work.

Fun Facts to File Under ‚ÄúDid You Know?‚Äù
- The cathedral was constructed on sand-filled grounds to withstand earthquakes ‚Äî a wise move in a seismically active region.
- It houses the grave of Archbishop Hubert D‚ÄôRosario, a revered figure who served the region with tireless devotion.
- During Christmas and Easter, the cathedral is a beacon of celebration, with elaborate nativity displays, lights, and hymns that can warm even the chilliest Shillong night.

Reverent Review
The cathedral isn‚Äôt just a monument, it‚Äôs a meditative experience in blue and white. Whether you're religious or simply a lover of quiet architecture, this place offers solace. The chirping of birds, the whiff of incense, and the echo of prayers create a soundtrack that stays with you long after you leave.

Pro Tip: Visit on a weekday morning. Less crowd, more calm. And don‚Äôt forget to light a candle ‚Äì sometimes, peace starts with a flicker.

The Cathedral of Mary Help of Christians in Shillong is a serene and stunning place of worship. Its striking architecture, peaceful atmosphere, and beautiful stained glass windows make it a true spiritual and visual experience. Surrounded by greenery and perched on a quiet hill, it‚Äôs a perfect spot for reflection and appreciation of local history and faith. A must-see landmark in the city.

A very beautiful church with lots of history and many sayings. It has a double stored building type structure which is pretty good. Also, the color of the church matches with the sky and I heard somewhere this church can withstand earthquakes as well. They have made this church so beautiful. Before going, read about the history of the church and then go. There is a packing space also for vehicles on the top and there are some associations as well. It feels good to be there for some time.

Most Beautiful Church in Shillong. A Soulful & Unforgettable Experience!

Even though I‚Äôm a Hindu, I‚Äôve always felt drawn to peaceful, spiritual places  and this church in Shillong truly touched my heart. It's beautifully built across a large area and has two levels  both the upper and lower sections are stunning and calm.

The entire church is so picturesque that I couldn‚Äôt stop taking photos. Every corner was beautiful and serene. But beyond the beauty, what made this visit unforgettable was a very special moment.

I wanted to light candles as a prayer, but unfortunately, there was no shop nearby. I was a little disappointed. Just then, a local person saw me and kindly offered me a candle. When I tried to pay, he smiled and said,
"You‚Äôve come to God‚Äôs house  it‚Äôs free. Please take it."
That moment was so pure and touching. I‚Äôll never forget his kindness  it made my entire trip feel truly blessed.

This place is not just a church; it‚Äôs an experience of peace, humility, and connection  beyond religion. Whether you're spiritual or not, this is a place you must visit in Shillong.

Highly recommended  truly a must-visit! üôè‚ú®
Very beautiful and iconic cathedral of Shillong. A must visit place where one can spend quality time enjoying the splendid beauty of nature amidst the city.

Nestled in the serene hills of Meghalaya, this majestic structure is not only an important center of Catholic worship but also a symbol of peace and devotion for people of all faiths. Its stunning Gothic-inspired architecture, stained glass windows, and tranquil surroundings create an atmosphere of deep reverence and reflection. A visit to the cathedral offers both a spiritual experience and a glimpse into the rich religious traditions of Northeast India.

reviews.reviewText: It's a museum to celebrate the rich military history of the North East area from the days of the British Raj. The museum is free to visit, no tickets are required. It has a lot of photographs along with information. If you read it all, it will easily take the day. I spent the evening there, we have to mark entry at the entrance. One personnel always guides to the entrance. It was an evening well spent.

If you are a history buff or a patriot, you MUST visit this place. The place is maintained very well by the army with a guide stationed there. They have good replicas of the weapons (incl guns) used in 1971 war and 1999 war. The pictures and details of the lieutenants and commanders and generals given are worth visiting.

The Rhino Heritage Museum in Shillong was a pleasant surprise for me, and I‚Äôd rate it 5/5. It may not be very large, but it carries a lot of character and history. The exhibits give a strong sense of the region‚Äôs past, including its military connections, and I found it engaging without feeling overwhelming.

The building itself has a certain old-world charm, and being inside the cantonment area makes the visit feel a little special. While the collection isn‚Äôt massive, it‚Äôs thoughtfully put together, and the stories behind the displays left an impression on me.

For anyone interested in culture and history, it‚Äôs definitely worth a stop. Short, simple, but memorable‚ÄîI really enjoyed the visit.

The Ever Living Museum in Shillong is a hidden gem, a sanctuary of history, nature, and knowledge nestled in the serene embrace of lush greenery. I had the privilege of being among the first batch of interns there, and the experience was nothing short of extraordinary.

The museum itself is a treasure trove, with its Stone Museum showcasing an exquisite collection of rare stones, fossils, and countless other marvels that tell stories of time immemorial. Every artifact seems to whisper secrets of the past, making it a paradise for those who cherish history and nature.

What makes this place truly special, however, is the soul behind it‚Äîthe owner, a remarkably humble and down-to-earth man with an astonishing depth of knowledge about virtually everything. His passion is contagious, and his dedication to preserving and sharing knowledge is truly inspiring. The entire team at the museum is just as warm and welcoming, making every visitor feel at home.

The peaceful and calming environment adds to the museum‚Äôs charm, making it not just a place of learning but also a retreat for the soul. I sincerely hope that this museum gains the recognition it truly deserves and continues to flourish, touching more lives with its beauty and wisdom.

The Wankhar Entomology Museum is a small museum located in Shillong, the capital city of the northeastern Indian state of Meghalaya. The museum is named after its founder, Late Mr. Wankhar, who was a renowned entomologist and had a passion for collecting insects.

The museum houses a collection of over 10,000 insect specimens, including rare and exotic species from India and other parts of the world. The collection includes butterflies, moths, beetles, spiders, and other insects, which are displayed in glass cases.

The museum aims to promote the study of entomology and raise awareness about the importance of insects in the ecosystem. Visitors can learn about the different types of insects, their anatomy, behavior, and habitats through the exhibits and displays.

The Wankhar Entomology Museum is a popular attraction for nature lovers, students, and researchers interested in entomology. The museum is open to the public on weekdays, and admission is free

reviews.reviewText: Shillong View Point, also known as Laitkor Peak, truly deserves a 5-star rating. As the highest point in Meghalaya, at 1966 meters, the panoramic views are simply breathtaking. Located roughly 10 kilometers from Shillong city, the journey to the peak is an experience in itself. You'll need to park at the ticket counter and then take a short taxi ride through an Indian Air Force area, which adds a unique touch. The drive, though only 3 kilometers, is a peaceful and scenic ascent, maintained at a gentle 30 km/h. Keep in mind that this tranquil spot closes relatively early, around 4 PM, so plan your visit accordingly. The serene atmosphere and stunning vistas make it an unforgettable destination.

Shillong Viewpoint at Laitkor Peak was a mixed experience for me. The view itself is absolutely breathtaking‚Äîyou get a sweeping panorama of the city, the hills, and on a clear day it feels magical, almost like floating above the clouds. That part really lived up to the hype and made the visit memorable.

What disappointed me, though, was how commercialized the whole place felt. Instead of focusing on showcasing culture or giving visitors a deeper experience of the region, everything seemed centered around selling things‚Äîphoto ops in traditional Khasi attire, snacks, and trinkets. The charm of the natural setting gets a bit overshadowed by the push for money.

Despite that, I can‚Äôt deny the beauty of the viewpoint itself. The scenery makes it worth a visit, but the experience could have been so much richer if it celebrated the culture as much as the view. For me, it‚Äôs a solid 4/5.

The mosque hosts a school committed to providing high-quality education, shaping young minds with a focus on excellence. Adjacent to this educational institution is a sprawling library, housing an extensive collection of books on Islam. What sets this library apart is its inclusivity, featuring materials in a multitude of languages, thereby becoming a beacon of knowledge accessible to a diverse audience.

The architecture extends beyond the prayer halls, with a meticulously designed sitting area that beckons visitors to immerse themselves in the world of literature. The intention behind its layout is evident‚Äîa space that not only accommodates reading but encourages it, fostering an atmosphere of reflection and tranquility.

Particularly noteworthy are the Islamic classes held in the library on specific days. This community-oriented initiative further establishes the mosque as a center for both spiritual and intellectual growth. It opens its doors not only to the Muslim community but also extends a warm welcome to individuals of all backgrounds, making it a cultural and educational hub for Shillong.

In essence, this mosque transcends religious boundaries, emerging as a cultural landmark and educational haven. Its architectural magnificence, coupled with a commitment to knowledge and community, renders it a must-visit destination‚Äîeven for those outside the Muslim faith.

The Mahadev Khola Dham is an age old temple located in the city of Shillong - Meghalaya. The temple is dedicated to Lord Mahadev and is said to be more than 150 years old. It is situated about 4 Kms from Shillong city and can be reached by taxis, city buses and private cars. The devotees need to walk about 300 meters from the main Gate of the temple as the path is not meant for four wheelers. The temple is situated in the midst of hills in a beautiful, picturesque location. The small stream flowing around the temple adds to its beauty. There are other temples  dedicated to Hindu Gods in the premises. Maha Shivaratri is celebrated with great fervour and a large number of devotees visit this temple. The wheelchair is inaccessible due to the steep slope on the way to the temple. There is no specified parking place for the devotees, while entry to the temple is free. Puja items are available in the shops near the temple. Drinkable water is available in the premises of the temple. Overall, a must visit place for all.

At a distance of 5 km from Shillong Bus Stand, Mahadev Khola Dham is an ancient Hindu temple located in Shillong, Meghalaya. It is one of the oldest temples in Meghalaya and among the famous places of pilgrimage in Shillong.

Believed to be about 150 years old, the Mahadev Khola Dham is a cave temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. According to legend, the temple is built at the spot where Lakhiya Baba, a sage was decided to stay and meditate. A subedar-major of 8th Gorkha Regiment dreamt of the sage mediating with a trishul (trident) in his hand and a rudraksh' necklace around his neck. The very next day, the man searched for the sage and found him at the place where the mandir' stands today. During the course of excavation for construction of the temple, the subedar-major found a huge shivling and thus the temple dedicated to Lord Shiva.

The present temple was built by several persons after independence, but the earlier one was built with the permission of the then British government. There is a small opening in the cave that leads to another cave. A small statue of Lord Shiva guards the entrance. It is believed that the opening leads to the ancient Kamakhya temple atop the Nilachal Hills in Kamrup, Assam directly. Apart from the main temple, there are many small temples in the complex, which are believed to have been built by devotees of Mahadev Khola Dham.

A grand mela of Lord Shiva is held for three days every year on the occasion of Maha Shivaratri at this temple. During the mela, more than 25,000 people visit the temple for the lord's blessings.
Courtesy:trawell.in

Mahadev Khola Dham is an ancient cave temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, located approximately 5 kilometers from the Shillong Bus Stand in Meghalaya. Believed to be around 150 years old, the temple is one of the oldest in the region and holds significant religious importance.

According to legend, a sage named Lakhiya Baba chose this cave for meditation. A Subedar-Major from the 8th Gorkha Regiment dreamt of the sage meditating with a trident and a rudraksha necklace. Upon searching, he discovered the sage at the current temple site. During excavation for the temple's construction, a large Shiva Lingam was found, leading to the establishment of the temple dedicated to Lord Shiva.

The temple complex includes several smaller shrines built by devotees whose wishes were believed to have been fulfilled. An annual three-day fair is held during Maha Shivaratri, attracting over 25,000 devotees seeking blessings.

Spread over a sprawling area of 1.5 km, The Botanical Garden is a haven of natural beauty. The variety of flora and fauna found here is simply mesmerizing. Walking through the garden, I was amazed by the diverse range of trees, shrubs, and flowers, üå∫including the stunning orchids and rhododendrons. The garden's vibrant colors and fragrant aromas truly enchanted me.

What sets The Botanical Garden apart is its thriving wildlife. The garden is home to numerous species of birds and butterflies, adding a touch of liveliness to the surroundings. It's a paradise for nature lovers, offering countless opportunities to observe and appreciate the wonders of the animal kingdom.

The garden itself is meticulously maintained, with well-laid pathways that guide visitors through its picturesque landscapes. Along the way, there are comfortable benches where one can relax and soak in the tranquil ambiance. Taking a leisurely stroll through this enchanting place was a therapeutic experience, providing a much-needed escape from the hustle and bustle of city life.

The Botanical Garden also offers additional attractions. A small children's park provides a safe and enjoyable space for little ones to play and explore. Additionally, the presence of a serene lake allows visitors to engage in boating activities, adding an extra element of fun to the overall experience.

If you find yourself in Shillong, a trip to The Botanical Garden is an absolute must. Whether you are a nature enthusiast or simply appreciate the beauty of the outdoors, this place will leave you awe inspired. I highly recommend visiting this gem of a garden and immersing yourself in its natural splendor. ‚ú®

The Botanical Garden in Shillong, also known as the Lady Hydari Park, is a popular tourist attraction located in the heart of the city. The park is named after Lady Hydari, the wife of the Governor of Assam, and was established in 1890.

The Botanical Garden is spread over an area of 1.5 km and is home to a variety of flora and fauna. The garden boasts of a wide variety of trees, shrubs, and flowers, including several species of orchids and rhododendrons. It is also home to several species of birds and butterflies, making it a haven for nature lovers.

The garden has several well-maintained pathways and benches for visitors to sit and enjoy the beauty of the surroundings. It is a great place to take a leisurely stroll and soak in the serene atmosphere. The garden also has a small children's park and a small lake where visitors can go boating.

The Botanical Garden is open to visitors from 9:00 am to 4:30 pm every day, and there is an entry fee of Rs. 10 per person. It is a must-visit attraction for anyone visiting Shillong, especially for those who appreciate nature and its beauty.
A perfect place to spend time. Green spread everywhere, a lake in the middle with boating facility. Ducks playing in the lake. Beautiful flowers will change your mind to good. Nice place to visit.

A hidden gem nestled in the serene pine forests of Shillong, ML 05 Cafe is an absolute must-visit for any food and travel enthusiast. The cafe's unique, motor-themed ambiance, which celebrates the region's love for bikes and cars, is both quirky and inviting. With a Royal Enfield motorcycle hanging from the ceiling and clever use of vehicle parts for decor, the atmosphere is unlike any other.

The real star of the show, however, is the food. I ordered the Bombay sandwich, the chef's special Maggi, and the noodles, and each dish was bursting with flavor and made to perfection. The menu offers a delightful mix of hearty Italian and Chinese dishes, local favorites, and creative street-food-inspired options. The presentation was beautiful, and the taste was even better‚Äîtrue comfort food that warms the soul.

Beyond the amazing food and cool decor, the cafe's location itself is a treat, offering stunning views of the surrounding natural beauty. The staff is attentive and the service is terrific, making you feel relaxed and welcomed. It's the perfect spot to unwind after a visit to the nearby Elephant Falls or to simply enjoy a cozy evening with friends. ML 05 Cafe is more than just a place to eat; it‚Äôs a destination that captures the heart with its serene vibe and delicious offerings.

Worst food I've ever tasted. I was really excited to try their famous burger but behold, there was no proper meat in my meat burger. The patty was like a mixture of 20% meat and some other fillers. I had spaghetti with meatballs- mediocre, and onion rings- horrible. Will never eat from here ever again.

The place is awesome + very delicious burger's and many items‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçüî• The Burger's are the best part of the cafe + it makes a better combination togetherüçîüåØüòã the Wraps are too delicious too one of the only place and most delicious Burger's and Wraps of all time in ShillongüåØüçîüòã
The food is not that great but if you enjoy cigarette smoke and hanging out with friends on hot summer evenings in Shillong, this is the place to be.

worst experience, pathetic service and top of it the burger served was a point close to zero. that's not how you make your burger and call it a burger. no taste and quantity was also lower class if we compare it to its price. it wasn't even worth it at all.

placeMetadata.name: BreadCafe

sources.snippet: This quaint cafe in Shillong is not just famous for its aesthetically pleasing interiors and vibe but also for its delectable food. It has huge glass windows from where you may enjoy the scenery outside and it brightens up the place. On top of the great ambience, their Instagram page is drool-worthy!
sources.shortName: 12 Instagram-Worthy Cafes In Shillong You Must Hit When In Town

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: BreadCafe is a well-established eatery located in the bustling Police Bazar of Shillong. This cafe has been serving its patrons for around a decade and is known for its delectable German pastries. While not exclusively vegetarian, BreadCafe offers an array of fresh and vegetarian snacks, sandwiches, pastries, and coffee to cater to diverse preferences. It's also renowned for its tempting dessert selection including cheesecakes and chocolate cakes.
placeMetadata.address: HVCW+FFF, Main Road, opp. Post Office, Nongkynrih, Laitumkhrah, Shillong, Meghalaya 793003, India

reviews.reviewText: I really liked this cafe. They always have the best cakes at affordable prices, even the food was good, the service was prompt and quick. Would definitely visit it again‚ú®üëçüèª

COCKROACHES ON CAKE!!!

We were in shillong for holidays and went to have cheesecake at this place. We parcelled the cheese cake and while billing i saw cockroaches roaming outside as well as on the cake! Basic hygiene is not there. it was disgusting and the staff acted very casually.  They should take hygiene seriously. They are playing with people‚Äôs health

So they extended the cafe area,it looks great inside. The range of menu also has increased. The sandwiches were very good, and the mocktails looked absolutely stunning. The German chocolate pastry was too chocolaty for me though. Overall loved the ambience ‚ú®

The food was delicious yum. The veg burger was filled with a surprise element of panner and the chicken wrap was enough to enjoy as a brunch. I will loved to visit and enjoy more items in the menu. The price is reasonable as well
The chicken sausage wrap had an average flavor, while the hot dog was quite good. However, the BBQ pasta stood out as my absolute favorite; its taste was simply extraordinary.

The butter chicken masala we ordered from this cafe was a disaster..  it was only tossed in tomato puree with less Masala and the colour of the curry looks like food colored curry (red) ü§¢ the curry was soo sweet it tasted like dessert , there was no spice no masala just tomato puree with some salt. Soo disappointing never tasted such butter chicken in my life till now !!! Please don't make butter chicken like that if you can't make it in a proper way!!!!!

Had a bad experience. We wanted to order Chicken Steak, but the staff replied that it would take time to prepare as they are having too many online orders. So let me warn you friends that greater importance is given to online customers.

We then ordered Royal Pasta and to our surprised we were served with BBQ Pasta. Also the menu stated that Dinner Rolls will be served along with the Pasta, but we did not receive it. I asked for the same and they simply replied "it is finished". So friends, are they not misleading us with the menu?

Strolled in after dinner to treat the kids and left with utter disgust after we received our order.  The cheesecake we ordered looked fine in the display case but it's only when we stuck the fork in that we realised we had been fooled as they were utterly stale and rubbery.  By far the worst cheesecake or dessert we've ever tasted.  The chap at the cash counter couldn't be bothered to even acknowledge our complaint.  Left after having just a couple of spoons since it was that inedible.  Do your stomachs and wallets a big favour and avoid this place peddling junk in the name of dessert!  Shameful!

placeMetadata.name: Open Up Cafe

sources.snippet: Located a little on the outskirts of the city, the Open Up cafe is a great place to experience some solitude and at the same time, a must-go place for families too. It has the brightest interiors, a variety of food items and games too. So, if you have kids, this place will not be a disappointment.
sources.shortName: 12 Instagram-Worthy Cafes In Shillong You Must Hit When In Town

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled on the outskirts of Shillong, Open Up Cafe is a charming comic-themed eatery that has transformed what was once a house into a vibrant space filled with bright red walls and whimsical comic art. This delightful cafe is not just about aesthetics; it serves up some of the city's best comfort food, including mouthwatering burgers, delectable hot dogs, and crispy chicken wings. The menu also features standout dishes like wonton noodle soup and Tom Yum soup, making it a haven for food lovers.
placeMetadata.address: Mawlai, Mawroh, Pdengshnong, Meghalaya 793008, India

reviews.reviewText:
Came here after so many years, love it back then and still love it just as much if not more now!

Today i tried the Pulled Pork Tacos, Fries with Cheese, Roast Beef and the Pork Chop and as for the drinks i tried the Hot chocolate, Cold Coffee with Ice Cream and Peach Iced Tea.

Each and every single item was absolutely delicious and very well prepared and you could see and taste the love that was put into it from the juicy tender pork to the crispy salty fries to the refreshing peach iced tea, everything was absolutely great.

I'd definitely recommend visiting and trying out this fine establishment and its delicious dishes.

Good cafe to spend a evening or afternoon

Service was quick
Food was good but not great‚Ä¶
Hot chocolate was very good

The taste can be improve

Staff were nice and well behaved

A bit expensive but yeah nothing is cheap in Shillong üòÖ
Good places to click family pictures

Following a prolonged wait, we finally returned to Open Up Cafe, enjoying an amazing time and delicious food. Consistency still remains intact. Service time has improved substantially compared to the past, and the waitress's warm welcome was notable. Our orders included chicken steak with mashed potatoes and chicken spaghetti, both of which were satisfactory. In beverages, we chose red ginger tea, which was impressive.
Love the ambience and yummy food. The place has a homely feeling to it served with good food, hygienic and good service. Would recommend visiting it during late afternoon or evenings.

The beef burger was very meaty with cheese and onion. The price is on the higher side but the size is big and felling.
The outdoor sitting was little small. The ambience was good otherwise.

The hot chocolate was truly delightful, I absolutely loved it. Encouraged by others' recommendations, we opted for the beef burger, known to be the best. However, I was somewhat disappointed by its size, especially considering the 420-rupee price tag‚ÄîI had expected a bit more. Nevertheless, the taste didn't disappoint. To compensate, we ordered the beef spaghetti meatballs, which turned out to be quite good. Overall, the food leans towards the pricey side, and while the taste is satisfactory, it doesn't reach extraordinary heights. On the positive side, the ambiance adds to the overall experience.

Better food. Good quality and quantity. A little bit expensive. But the food is worth the price. Outstanding ambience inside and outside the cafe. Traffic near the cafe is not that much. Will be 3 or 4 out of 10. The ambience and food quality will be 9 out of 10. Waiting time is not that much. Perfect spot for couples, friends, and families as well.

Ordered golden fried prawns but we got rings onions and 5 or 6 pieces of prawns which was also not good. It is not fair to write fried prawns and serve a plate full on onion rings.
Had also ordered tacos which was not even prepared like a Taco it was more like a bao. The ambience and service was really very good but i think they should work on improving the food quality.

placeMetadata.name: Police Bazar - Main Market of Shillong

sources.snippet: Police Bazar is the main market of Shillong, and a famous shopping area for local‚Äôs area and travelers alike. In addition to a range of restaurants, hotels and big brand stores, the Police Bazaar also has a flea market which is pocket-friendly and draws the highest number of travelers due to its cultural handicraft shops, beautiful Meghalaya merchandise, local apparels, rubbish jewelry and the like. The vibrant market is throng by shopping enthusiasts as well as foodies.
sources.shortName: Top Places to Visit in Shillong Meghalaya, The Scotland of the East

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Police Bazar, the main market of Shillong, is a bustling and lively paradise for tourists. It offers a wide range of shopping options from unique bamboo handicrafts to traditional Khasi clothing and souvenirs. The market is filled with stalls and shops selling everything from winter clothing to local spices. Visitors can also enjoy delicious food at various cafes in the area.
placeMetadata.address: HVGM+C3P, Police Bazar, Shillong, Meghalaya 793001, India

reviews.reviewText: I visited Shillong during winter, and exploring Police Bazar was one of the highlights of my trip. It‚Äôs a lively local market with a great selection of affordable winter wear ‚Äî coats, shoes, shirts, and more. I also found a wide variety of keychains, which I really loved. There are spacious roadside eateries nearby as well, and the food was absolutely delicious ‚Äî definitely a must-try! You‚Äôll also find many varieties of chillies there, which are really spicy and unique. If you're visiting Meghalaya, make sure not to leave without experiencing Police Bazar.One of the best parts was the lighting at night ‚Äî it looked so beautiful! Although the market closes a bit early, the overall vibe in the evening is amazing. Totally worth visiting!

It‚Äôs also called as Police bazaar where you can shop for local Shawl of Shillong and many more things.
It‚Äôs a local market and very crowded place with lovely people. It‚Äôs good to negotiate here otherwise you know like every place in India you will be looted.
People are lovely and everybody helped each other.

It's almost like T nagar of Chennai, paharganj of Delhi , majestic area of Bangalore, Malad market of Mumbai. There is a heavy turnout of people in the market. Sweater, shawl, kurti, shorts , different types of tops, miniskirts
The Best Option for Street Shopping at Shillong. You will also get a Wide array of Local Handicraft Products in this Street Market. Anybody who loves Street Shopping would Enjoy this Market.

Most happening place. It is just the centre of shillong which is called the police bazar. You can get many stores and all from footpath where sweaters, jackets and bags are available. You need to bargain a bit but also the price is not too high. You will love to shop from the police bazaar.

Police bazar is the most busy yet lively market of Shillong. It‚Äôs a paradise for tourists to enjoy delicious food and do lots of shopping. There is so much to do in the market, do try the momos specifically the veg ones. One can get clothes, souvenirs and many other items at a very reasonable price. There are few cafes in the market as well. The market closes at 10 PM üïô so visit accordingly ü§üüèª
It's the heart of Shillong city. Though often crowded, the cool weather, the mouth-watering aroma of street food, and the vibrant colors offer a sensory experience that‚Äôs hard to forget

Market in one road, variety of items can be available with food corner, fruits and many more items. Physical handicapped accessible market. Rates can be negotiated with shop owners.
It is located at center point of city.

placeMetadata.name: Sweet Falls

sources.snippet: One of the steepest and the most exciting falls of the country, the Sweet Falls are located just about 5 km from Happy Valley in Shillong. At an elevation of 96 meters, it is often touted as the most spectacular yet most unsafe waterfall. The way to the waterfall is not maintained and is rather deceitful, bounded by smooth stones resulting in some awful stories.
sources.shortName: Top Places to Visit in Shillong Meghalaya, The Scotland of the East

placeMetadata.address: HX65+FJV, Mawshbuit-Sweet Falls Rd, Meghalaya 793108, India

reviews.reviewText: Beautiful spot for sight seeing. You can easily visit the area from 58 GTC area. However, it‚Äôs prohibited to go till waterfall view dangerous path and route downhill.

It's a nice place not so far away from the city. The entry fee is also affordable. They've renovated some of the entrance spots. Spot will be good for photography. Although I don't think the waterfall is accessible (correct me if I'm wrong) so that might seem a bit disappointing. Also there's no shop nearby(atleast 500m+). In summary, it's a nice place for a small hangout, the air is fresh and crispy which set the perfect atmosphere to crack open a couple of cold ones.
If you're a tourist, I recommend renting scooty while going for this spot. That way you can also move ahead of schedule and visit more places.
Nice view of the waterfall from a distance...lots of wilderness...and scared of black caterpillars...
Sweet fall you can go at bathing point. Going to this point is the best adventure of our life. sweet is most beautiful place down.
Sweet fall really sweet, nic view
Its a small plunge fall located at happy valley about 15 kms away from Shillong city. The view point is not a crowded place usually.
Nice view sweet fall
Amezing water falls

A visit to XTSY Waterfalls promises a refreshing escape into nature without straying far from urban conveniences.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Nestled in the lush hills of Northeast India, Shillong is a city that seems to have been painted by nature itself. With its rolling landscapes, cascading waterfalls, and vibrant culture, it‚Äôs no wonder that this charming destination is often referred to as the 'Scotland of the East.' Whether you‚Äôre gazing at the breathtaking views from Shillong Peak or capturing the serene beauty of Elephant Falls, every corner of this city offers a picture-perfect moment waiting to be discovered.

As you wander through the streets of Shillong, you‚Äôll find a delightful mix of historical landmarks and natural wonders. From the stunning architecture of the Cathedral of Mary Help of Christians to the tranquil ambiance of Lady Hydari Park, there‚Äôs no shortage of spots that will make your camera click. The Wanderlog team is passionate about uncovering these hidden gems and iconic sites, inviting you to explore the best photo opportunities that Shillong has to offer. Grab your camera and get ready to capture the essence of this enchanting city!
